Description: Your sequence identifier; should match the FASTA file header - this is used to link the metadata to the FASTA sequence
The date on which the sample was collected. Please format YYYY-MM-DD - use XX if unknown, ex: `2020-03-XX` or `20XX-XX-XX`, and provide _at least_ year
The country from which the sample was collected.
A local administrative region from which the sample was collected (ex: Province, State, Canton)
A local administrative region from which the sample was collected (ex: county or municipality)
The city from which the sample was collected.
The name of a specific geographical location e.g. Credit River (rather than river).
If there is another sample ID attached to the sequence, it can be recorded here (nothing identifiable!)
An ID useful to linking to a culture
If a laboratory host (e.g. cultured cell line) was used to propagate the sample.
Population of cells derived from a single cell or group of cells, which are cultured in the laboratory under controlled conditions
The number of times a cell culture has been subcultured or transferred from one vessel to another.
The techniques used to subculture cells
The date on which the sample was received by the laboratory.
Method of sampling.
The reason that the sample was collected.
The activities or variables introduced upstream of sample collection that may affect the sample collected.
A substance obtained from an anatomical part of an organism e.g. tissue, blood, saliva, fluid (Cerebrospinal (CSF), Pericardial, Pleural, Vaginal, Amniotic)
The anatomical part of the organism the sample was taken from e.g. oropharynx.
A substance excreted/secreted from an organism e.g. feces, urine, sweat.
A substance obtained from the natural or man-made environment e.g. soil, water, sewage, door handle, bed handrail, face mask.
An environmental location may describe a site in the natural or built environment e.g. hospital, wet market, bat cave.
The instrument or container used to collect the sample e.g. swab.
The process used to collect the sample e.g. phlebotomy, necropsy.
A material consumed and digested for nutritional value or enjoyment. Include animal feed.
Any characteristic of the food product pertaining to its state, processing, a label claim, or implications for consumers.
The processing applied to samples post-collection, prior to further testing, characterization, or isolation procedures.
Detailed information regarding the processing applied to a sample during or after receiving the sample.
Example: 25 swabs were pooled and further prepared as a single sample during library prep.

Description: The type of role that the sample represents in the experiment.
The age of the host at the time of sample collection.
The age category of the host at the time of sampling.
The gender of the host.
The country of origin of the host.
The name of the disease experienced by the host.
A perceived change in function or sensation, (loss, disturbance or appearance) indicative of a disease, reported by a patient.
Health status of the host at the time of sample collection.
Disease outcome in the host.
Travel history in last six months.
Example: Canada, Vancouver; USA, Seattle; Italy, Milan

Description: Event leading to exposure.
The role of the host in relation to the exposure setting.
The setting leading to exposure.
Additional host exposure information.
The name of the disease previously experienced by the host.
The name of the pathogen causing the disease previously experienced by the host.
The vaccination status of the host (fully vaccinated, partially vaccinated, or not vaccinated) - regarding current sampled pathogen.
The reason that the sample was sequenced.
Type of diagnostic test performed
Boolean value e.g. if the diagnostic target was present.
The name of the gene used in a diagnostic RT-PCR test
Value of the diagnostic test. Ex: The Ct value result from a diagnostic SARS-CoV-2 RT-PCR test
The units of the diagnostic test performed
The scientific name of the host from which the sample was collected.
The common name of the host from which the sample was collected.
Taxon ID for the host
The date the sample was sequenced.
The specifications of the primers (primer sequences, binding positions, fragment size generated etc) used to generate the amplicons to be sequenced.
The length of the amplicon generated by PCR amplification.
The model of the sequencing instrument used.
The protocol used to generate the sequence.
Example: Genomes were generated through amplicon sequencing of 1200 bp amplicons with Freed schema primers. Ligation sequencing kit SQK-LSK109 (Oxford Nanopore Technologies) was used for library preparation.

Description: The overarching sequencing methodology that was used to determine the sequence of a biomaterial.
The organization responsible for sequencing the sample.
The name or title of the contact responsible for follow-up regarding the sequence.
The email address of the contact responsible for follow-up regarding the sequence.
The method used for raw data processing such as removing barcodes, adapter trimming, filtering etc.
The method used to remove host reads from the pathogen sequence.
A persistent, unique identifier of a genome database entry.
The name of software used to generate the consensus sequence.
The version of the software used to generate the consensus sequence.
The average number of reads representing a given nucleotide in the reconstructed sequence.
The percentage of the reference genome covered by the sequenced data, at a prescribed depth (`depthOfCoverage`)
The name of the method used to assess whether a sequence passed a predetermined quality control threshold.
The version number of the method used to assess whether a sequence passed a predetermined quality control threshold.
The determination of a quality control assessment.
The reason contributing to, or causing, a low quality determination in a quality control assessment.
The details surrounding a low quality determination in a quality control assessment.
Example: CT value of 39. Low viral load. Low DNA concentration after amplification.

Description: List of authors who should be listed on the sample, comma delimited
List of author affiliations in the same order as authors, one entry per author
Example: EVE Group, MPI Department, Swiss TPH, Basel, Switzerland; Anderson Group, IEB Department, School of Biology, University of Edinburgh, Edinburgh, Scotland

Description: Reason for revising sequences or other general comments concerning a specific version
Example: Fixed an issue in previous version where low-coverage nucleotides were erroneously filled with reference sequence
